articles.title: Did you solve it? Wordplay wizardry by the UK’s king of quiz
articles.trailText: The answers to today’s puzzles
articles.summary: Solutions to Frank Paul’s wordplay set. 1) Grr! Ooo!: pairs where three consecutive consonants become three vowels — bursts/bureau; strengths/strenuous; lords/Louie (ex: mildly/milieu). 2) Strip tease: nested truncations — eclipse/clips/lip; jauntiest/aunties/untie; brashest/rashes/Ashe. 3) Word loop (AB, BC, CA): downside/sideshow/showdown; backside/sidesaddle/saddleback; piecemeal/mealtime/timepiece. 4) Rats!: hidden numbers seven/zero/eight (flip image). Author floats a coding challenge to enumerate such sets, esp. longer chains for #2; plugs Frank’s book Spin Off and invites puzzle submissions.

articles.title: Can you solve it? Wordplay wizardry by the UK’s king of quiz
articles.trailText: Conundrums for the crossword connoisseur
articles.summary: Pub-quiz star and Only Connect champion Frank Paul sets four wordplay challenges. 1) Grr! Ooo!: find twin words identical except three consecutive consonants become three consecutive vowels; clues: “Splits open; writing desk”, “Good qualities; requiring much exertion”, “Peers; a nephew of Donald Duck.” 2) Strip tease: three-word chains by trimming first/last letters; three clue triplets as prompts. 3) Word loop AB, BC, CA: three definition triplets to resolve. 4) Find three hidden adjacent numbers (not 4, 6, 3). Solutions at 5pm UK; NO SPOILERS. Promotes Paul’s choose-your-path puzzle book Spin Off (Guardian Bookshop) and invites reader puzzle submissions via email.

articles.title: Starwatch: can you spot Lacerta the lizard crawling across the night sky?
articles.trailText: Catching this distinctive but faint zigzag constellation will require a dark sky, well away from street lights
articles.summary: Faint yet distinctive, Lacerta (“the lizard”) sits between Cygnus, Cassiopeia and Andromeda, tracing a zigzag shape. From London it’s well placed around 19:30 GMT on 27 October (and similar all week), high in the southern sky. Despite lacking bright stars, it rewards dark‑sky observers away from street lights; the same conditions showcase Cygnus and the autumn Milky Way. Named in the 17th century by Johannes Hevelius to fill gaps between ancient constellations. Look for its kinked line of faint stars threading the Milky Way. As a northern constellation, Lacerta sits low for southern observers, hugging the northern horizon and proving a challenging target.

articles.title: Dinosaurs were thriving until asteroid struck, research suggests
articles.trailText: Dating of rock formation in New Mexico casts doubt on theory that species was already in decline
articles.summary: New dating of New Mexico's Naashoibito Member suggests North American dinosaurs were thriving until the asteroid impact. In Science, Andrew Flynn (New Mexico State Univ) used argon-isotope geochronology plus magnetostratigraphy to show the unit hosting the youngest fossils formed at most 350,000 years before the 66 Ma extinction, within a short reversed-polarity chron. Assemblages indicate high regional variation: north: Triceratops, Edmontosaurus; south: crested duck-bills and giant sauropods like 30 m Alamosaurus, alongside T. rex. Co-author Steve Brusatte sees no pre-impact decline; Flynn cites sampling bias. Michael Benton welcomes the data but notes it is one site and broader records show declines (43 to 30 species) in western North America.

articles.title: Weight-loss drug cuts heart attack risk regardless of kilograms shed, study finds
articles.trailText: Semaglutide study suggests such drugs could have wider benefits, though researchers find shrinking waistlines linked to better heart outcomes
articles.summary: Semaglutide (Wegovy) cut major adverse cardiovascular events (CV death, MI, stroke) regardless of kilograms lost, per a Lancet analysis of SELECT: 17,604 adults ≥45 with overweight/obesity across 41 countries randomized to weekly semaglutide vs placebo. Prior data showed ~20% MACE reduction; new mediation analysis found benefits largely independent of early (4‑month) weight loss and present even at BMI 27. Waist circumference reduction explained an estimated 33% of benefit, leaving ~67% unexplained—suggesting direct cardioprotection. UCL authors argue use shouldn’t be limited to highest BMIs or large weight loss, while emphasizing careful monitoring of side-effects.

articles.title: Darleane Hoffman obituary
articles.trailText: Scientist whose research into transuranic elements revised the understanding of nuclear fission
articles.summary: Darleane Hoffman (1926-2025), pioneering nuclear chemist at Los Alamos and Lawrence Berkeley, reshaped understanding of heavy-element chemistry and fission. In 1971 she identified naturally occurring plutonium-244 in Nevada test-site rocks and confirmed it at Mountain Pass, an experimental tour de force lauded by Glenn Seaborg. Analyzing fermium-257, she validated rare symmetric fission, overturning theory. She led Los Alamos's nuclear chemistry division, joined LBNL in 1978, confirmed element 106 (seaborgium) and studied up to hassium. Her work advanced medical radioisotopes, reactor safety, and nonproliferation. She directed the Seaborg Institute (1991-96), and Discover named her among the 50 most important women in science (2002).

articles.title: Antidepressants differ in side-effects such as weight gain, UK research finds
articles.trailText: Notable variations between different medications were found in weight gain or loss, heart rate and blood pressure
articles.summary: Review of 151 clinical studies (58,000+ participants) comparing 30 antidepressants finds large variation in short-term physical side-effects. Across mostly 8-week trials, average weight change differed by up to 4kg: agomelatine about -2.5kg vs maprotiline about +2kg; nearly half on maprotiline/amitriptyline gained weight, while more than 50% on agomelatine lost. Heart rate varied by 21 bpm (fluvoxamine vs nortriptyline) and blood pressure by 11 mmHg (nortriptyline vs doxepin). SSRIs generally showed fewer physical effects. Authors (King's College London/Oxford) urge updating treatment guidelines, closer monitoring for some drugs, and shared decision-making to personalise choices. Antidepressants, often used up to two years, benefit many but are not interchangeable.

articles.title: Scientists create pigs resistant to classical swine fever
articles.trailText: Gene-edited animals remained healthy when exposed to highly contagious deadly disease
articles.summary: Scientists at Edinburgh’s Roslin Institute used precise edits to DNAJC14 to create pigs resistant to classical swine fever (CSF). In APHA trials, four edited pigs remained healthy and aviraemic a week after challenge; four controls showed disease and high viral loads. The edit blocks pestivirus replication; multigenerational monitoring found no health or fertility costs. CSF is endemic in China, Russia and Brazil and has driven 75,000 UK culls since the 1960s. Similar edits are being tested in cattle and sheep. Regulation is loosening (UK Precision Breeding Act; US/Japan/Brazil approvals). Published in Trends in Biotechnology; Genus’s PRRS‑resistant pigs reach US market in 2026.

articles.title: Whistleblower resigns in protest after inquiry finds ‘no credible evidence’ of wrongdoing at SKA Observatory
articles.trailText: Organisation behind $3.6bn international project releases findings of report that found none of the claims of financial mismanagement had been upheld
articles.summary: An independent probe commissioned by the Square Kilometre Array Observatory (SKAO) found “no credible evidence” of financial mismanagement, rejecting all whistleblower claims about external trading accounts and procurement. UK firm Squire Patton Boggs led the inquiry despite being an SKAO client; the chair said firewalls ensured impartiality and investigators had unrestricted access and autonomy. The whistleblower resigned, alleging constructive dismissal and a culture suppressing transparency; an internal employment tribunal is pending. SKAO, a €2bn (A$3.6bn) 16-nation project, has Australia’s contribution rising by >A$150m since 2020 to A$475m (2021–25), partly due to funding shortfalls. The WA array runs at ~1% capacity, captured first galaxy images last year; rollout scope/schedule remain under review.

articles.title: How living history is being written into rocks
articles.trailText: Scientists are using DNA from sediments to learn more about past environments, including new revelations about the woolly mammoth
articles.summary: Sedimentary ancient DNA (sedaDNA) preserved by mineral binding offers new windows into past ecosystems where fossils are rare. It has revealed woolly mammoths persisted in the Arctic longer than thought and records soft-bodied taxa like worms. DNA traces from skin, hair, feces, urine, and pollen embed in soils and rocks for hundreds of thousands to millions of years. Tony Brown (University of Southampton) in Geoscientist describes mineral incorporation mechanisms. Norway studies align sedaDNA with animal cave art. Brown's PortGEN analyzes port sediments (Rome, Venice) to reconstruct ancient urban ecologies, trade, and disease. Field poised for rapid growth.

articles.title: Elon Musk feuds with US transportation chief in social media posts: ‘2 digit IQ’
articles.trailText: SpaceX owner said Sean Duffy was ‘trying to kill Nasa’ after acting head said agency would reopen contracts for Artemis mission
articles.summary: Elon Musk escalated a feud with Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy—also NASA’s acting chief—after Duffy said NASA will reopen Artemis lunar-lander contracts, citing SpaceX delays and hinting Blue Origin could win. On X, Musk called Duffy “Sean Dummy,” claimed he’s “trying to kill NASA,” and mocked his “2 digit IQ” and past as a champion lumberjack. The clash reflects a power struggle over NASA leadership: Musk backs SpaceX ally Jared Isaacman, whom Trump rejected earlier for Democratic donations, choosing Duffy instead. Duffy reportedly seeks to fold NASA under DOT. SpaceX holds NASA’s $2.9bn Artemis III lander award; the program has slipped, with the next lunar-orbit mission no earlier than 2026.

articles.title: Chen-Ning Yang obituary
articles.trailText: Theoretical physicist who won the Nobel prize for his work on the forces acting on fundamental subatomic particles
articles.summary: Chen-Ning (C.N.) Yang, 103 (1922–18 Oct 2025), Chinese American theorist, won the 1957 Nobel with Tsung-Dao Lee for discovering parity violation in weak interactions. Earlier, with Robert Mills (1953), he created gauge theories (Yang–Mills) that underpin the Standard Model: W bosons gain mass via the Higgs mechanism (confirmed 2012); gluons mediate QCD; QED is a gauge prototype. After IAS Princeton, he became Albert Einstein Professor at Stony Brook (1965–99), later at Tsinghua; he renounced US citizenship in 2015. He also advanced statistical mechanics/condensed matter; honors include the US National Medal of Science (1986) and Albert Einstein Medal (1995). Survived by wife Weng Fan and three children.

articles.title: Nasa looks to other companies for US moon program as Musk’s SpaceX lags behind
articles.trailText: Nasa head said agency is opening up contracts for crewed lunar program Artemis after SpaceX had to delay timelines
articles.summary: NASA will solicit additional bidders for Artemis crewed lunar landings because SpaceX is behind schedule, interim administrator and Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy told CNBC. SpaceX holds the $2.89bn Artemis III Starship HLS award but has suffered multiple Starship test failures since 2023, contributing to NASA’s shift of Artemis II to 2026 and Artemis III to mid-2027. Duffy aims to move Artemis II up to Feb 2026 and open competition to Blue Origin and others (Lockheed Martin, Northrop Grumman, Draper) to accelerate timelines amid a perceived race with China. Leadership shuffle: Jared Isaacman’s nomination was withdrawn; Duffy is interim.

articles.title: Experts hail ‘remarkable’ success of electronic implant in restoring sight
articles.trailText: Sight of 84% of people with form of age-related macular degeneration restored after being fitted with device
articles.summary: An ultrathin 2mm by 2mm retinal implant (Prima) restored central reading vision in 84% of 38 older patients with geographic atrophy from dry age-related macular degeneration, in a 17-site trial including Moorfields, UK. Implanted via a vitrectomy under two hours, the chip pairs with AR glasses and a waistband computer: the camera captures scenes, AI processes them, infrared is projected onto the chip, and signals pass via the retina and optic nerve. After rehabilitation, participants read letters, numbers and words, with major quality-of-life gains. Sites included Germany, France, Italy and the Netherlands. Results appeared in NEJM; experts called it a remarkable new era for AMD blindness.

articles.title: Orionid meteor shower: how stargazers can get the best views in Australia
articles.trailText: Early birds on the east coast will have the best chance of seeing this annual astral light show
articles.summary: Australia’s Orionid meteor shower—dust from Halley’s comet in a month-long debris stream—peaks Tuesday–Wednesday this week. Best viewing is pre-dawn: radiant rises ~10:30pm in Brisbane, is high near midnight in Sydney, and reaches its highest 4:00–4:30am AEDT. Set alarms for roughly 2:30–4:30am local (3:30–5:30am AEDT). Expect about 10–15 meteors/hour in dark, clear conditions. Meteors are sub–grain-of-rice particles striking the atmosphere at 12–72 km/s. Next up: the Geminids, peaking 14 December, typically 30–60 meteors/hour, best around 2–3am; strongest overall, slightly favoring the northern hemisphere.

articles.title: Starwatch: look east to catch the zippy Orionids meteor shower
articles.trailText: The speed of the shower creates swift, bright streaks across the night sky, at a typical rate of 20 meteors an hour
articles.summary: The Orionids are best seen in the early hours of 22 October; look east around 00:30 BST (London). Produced by debris from Halley’s Comet, these meteors strike at ~66 km/s, leaving swift, bright streaks and occasional fireballs. Many display persistent trains lasting seconds. Expect around 20 meteors per hour, though rates vary. 2025 conditions are favorable: a waning crescent Moon (~30% illuminated) rises in the early morning, giving dark skies until about 03:00 BST. In the northern hemisphere, Orion rises before midnight and climbs toward dawn; southern observers see Orion higher, potentially offering better views. Clear, moonless windows maximize counts.

articles.title: Smart jab can shrink head and neck cancer tumours within six weeks, trial finds
articles.trailText: Triple-action therapy drug amivantamab could be given as an injection to help treat recurrent or metastatic cancers
articles.summary: An early trial finds amivantamab, a triple-action subcutaneous smart jab, shrinks or halts recurrent/metastatic head and neck squamous cell carcinoma after immunotherapy and platinum chemo failure. In Orig-AMI 4 (ESMO Berlin), 86 previously treated patients received amivantamab; 76% had tumour shrinkage or disease control, with responses in about six weeks; median progression-free survival was 6.8 months. Side-effects were mostly mild to moderate. Amivantamab blocks EGFR and MET and activates immune attack. Injection delivery may enable faster outpatient or at-home care. Janssen-funded, 11-country study.

articles.title: Italian blasphemy and German ingenuity: how swear words differ around the world
articles.trailText: Once swearwords were dismissed as a sign of low intelligence, now researchers argue the ‘power’ of taboo words has been overlooked
articles.summary: Global 2024 study of taboo words in 13 languages/17 countries finds big cultural contrasts. Germans listed ~53 terms on average (vs ~16 in UK/Spain), helped by compounds (eg intelligenzallergiker, hodenkobold). Shit ranks high in English, Finnish, Italian, but not French, Dutch, Spanish, German. Gendered insults (eg bitch) are common, reflecting sexism; newer terms (eg feminazi) track politics. Italians supplied 24+ church-related profanities, including 17 variants of fucking God, tied to Catholic roots. Men and extroverts swear more; average once per two minutes. Swearing can hurt, bond, subvert, relieve stress, even boost pain tolerance (ice-hand test). Social media anonymity is linked to harsher, targeted language by race, religion, gender and sexuality.

articles.title: ‘Bored aliens’: has intelligent life stopped bothering trying to contact Earth?
articles.trailText: Astrophysicist proposes a ‘radically mundane’ theory for why humans have yet to encounter extraterrestrials
articles.summary: Astrophysicist Dr Robin Corbet (UMBC/NASA Goddard) proposes radical mundanity for the Fermi paradox: the Milky Way hosts only modestly advanced civilisations, tech just beyond ours (iPhone 42 vs iPhone 17). Lacking FTL or exotic physics, they cannot run million-year laser beacons, zip between stars, or build galaxy-scale megastructures; probes yield diminishing returns, so exploration stalls. The paper is unreviewed. Critics: Prof Michael Garrett (Jodrell Bank) says this anthropomorphises apathy; he favors post-biological civilisations advancing beyond detectability (Acta Astronautica). Prof Michael Bohlander (Durham) adds UAPs might already be evidence if a small fraction are not man-made.

articles.title: Plantwatch: An extraordinary orchid that lives and flowers underground
articles.trailText: Botanist trying to conserve highly vulnerable rhizanthella that survives by feeding on nutrients from a fungus
articles.summary: Rhizanthella, a leafless, fully subterranean Australian orchid, flowers below ground and survives as a mycoheterotroph: its seeds and stems feed via a symbiotic fungus linked to broom bush (Melaleuca uncinata) roots. First unearthed by a ploughing farmer in Western Australia in 1928, it remains notoriously hard to locate; blooms are tiny reddish florets wrapped in creamy-pink bracts, vanilla-scented, likely pollinated by termites or minute flies. Only five species exist, among the world’s rarest orchids, now highly vulnerable from habitat loss and drought driven by climate breakdown. UWA botanist Kingsley Dixon is racing to conserve them by co-culturing seeds with the fungus and transplanting to potted Melaleuca hosts.

articles.title: Did you solve it? The London cab that rode into history
articles.trailText: The answers to today’s questions
articles.summary: Solutions to three puzzles themed on 1729, the taxicab number. 1) Smallest number expressible as the sum of two squares in two ways (<100): 50 = 1^2 + 7^2 = 5^2 + 5^2. 2) With strips 1, 2, 7, 17, 29 cm, add one distinct strip ≤29 so no three can form a triangle: valid lengths are 3, 4, 5 cm; bonus: these extras alone form a 3-4-5 right triangle. Correction noted: prior 9 cm was an error; all lengths distinct. 3) Given five pairwise products 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, the missing sixth product is 12/5 = 2.4. Submissions invited.

articles.title: Lab-grown human embryo model produces blood cells
articles.trailText: Breakthrough raises new possibilities for regenerative medicine, which uses patient’s own cells to repair damaged tissues
articles.summary: University of Cambridge’s Gurdon Institute grew stem-cell embryo models (no placenta, yolk sac or brain; non-viable) that recapitulate week 3–4 development and autonomously produce human blood. By day 2, ectoderm/mesoderm/endoderm formed; day 8, beating heart cells; day 13, red blood patches and hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells that differentiated into red cells and immune white cells. The system mirrors natural development without exogenous protein cocktails, enabling patient-matched blood from reprogrammed cells. Uses: alternatives to bone-marrow transplants, regenerative therapies, drug screening, studying early blood/immune development, leukemia modeling. Led by Jitesh Neupane and Azim Surani; published in Cell Reports.

articles.title: Can you solve it? The London cab that rode into history
articles.trailText: Do you have the knowledge?
articles.summary: Guardian puzzle riffs on Ramanujan’s taxicab 1729—smallest number as two cubes two ways—and announces the UK’s first specialist maths secondary school, the 1729 Maths School, opening next September at Mill Hill, London (Y7=18, Y9=10; bursaries; apply by 31 Oct; backed by Alex and Elena Gerko/XTX Markets). Puzzles: 1) Smallest number <100 expressible as sum of two squares in two different ways. 2) Strips 1,2,7,17,29 cm; add one distinct whole‑cm length ≤29 so no three form a triangle; how many lengths, which, plus bonus shape. 3) Of ab,ac,ad,bc,bd,cd, five are 2,3,4,5,6; find the sixth. Clarifications: ≤29 max, unique lengths; error fixed; answers 5pm.

articles.title: Starwatch: worth staying up for pleasing view of moon encountering Jupiter and Gemini
articles.trailText: Conjunction just after midnight on 14 October will show brightest stars of Gemini shining brightly below moon
articles.summary: Just after midnight on 14 October, a Moon–Jupiter–Gemini conjunction is worth a look. From London at 00:30 BST, face east: the Moon is near last quarter (47% illuminated), marking the transition from waning gibbous to waning crescent. Below it shine brilliant Jupiter and Gemini’s twins, Castor and Pollux. Jupiter now rises in Gemini about midnight and remains conspicuous into morning twilight. Gemini will be visible until dawn, giving night owls and early risers ample time. In the southern hemisphere, observe in the early hours toward the north‑east; the meeting should be clear before dawn.

articles.title: Drummond Rennie obituary
articles.trailText: Doctor and medical editor who inaugurated the International Congress on Peer Review and Scientific Publication
articles.summary: Drummond Rennie (1936–2025), British-born nephrologist turned leading US medical editor, died aged 89. Deputy editor at NEJM (1977–81) and JAMA (1983–2013), he crusaded to fix flawed peer review and reporting, founding the International Congress on Peer Review and Scientific Publication (1989). At JAMA he advanced RCT reporting (1994) that evolved into CONSORT, championed prospective trial registration (helping spur clinicaltrials.gov, 2000), and exposed Brown & Williamson’s suppression of nicotine-addiction research (1994). He served on the US Commission on Research Integrity (1995) and led JAMA’s Users’ Guides to the Medical Literature (1993–2000). A mountaineer and teacher at Rush and UC, he is survived by wife Deborah Peltzman, two children and two granddaughters.

articles.title: Why it’s worth taking a wider look at biarchal cultures | Letters
articles.trailText: Letter: In places such as Canada, the US, parts of Africa, southern India and Polynesia, biarchal traditions are almost within living memory, says Simon Dawson
articles.summary: Letter argues Laura Spinney's piece on prehistoric egalitarianism is Eurocentric, overlooking regions where biarchal (shared gender governance) traditions lasted into near living memory: Canada, US, parts of Africa, southern India, Polynesia. Cites Mount Allison University's Mi'kmaw Women - Strength of a Nation on colonialism, mission schools and Christian patriarchy dismantling Mi'kmaw female autonomy. References a 2022 Guardian report on Kikuyu heritage: women led agriculture; culture was matrilineal, sexually liberal before European suppression. Adds many biarchal societies revered gender-variant people in spiritual roles. Author: Simon Dawson.

articles.title: Grisly recording reveals bat catching, killing and eating robin mid-flight
articles.trailText: Before the Spanish study, some scientists had been sceptical about the mammals attacking migratory birds
articles.summary: Spanish researchers fitted Europe’s largest bat, the greater noctule, with backpack loggers (audio, acceleration, altitude) in southern Spain and captured the first definitive evidence of avian predation mid-flight. One bat climbed to 1.2 km, pursued a migrating robin >1 km in a dive, eliciting 21 distress calls, then delivered a fatal bite and chewed continuously for 23 minutes while flying low, never losing altitude. Two attacks were recorded; one succeeded. Prior clues (faecal feathers, severed wings with DNA/X-ray) now validated. Bats likely discard wings to cut drag and feed using the hind-leg membrane pouch. Findings in Science; species is threatened by drought and wildfires.

articles.title: Sir Peter Hirsch obituary
articles.trailText: Scientist who transformed the understanding of materials and redefined our knowledge of crystallography
articles.summary: Sir Peter Bernard Hirsch (1925–2025), materials scientist, transformed crystallography by producing the first TEM images of crystalline defects. In 1956 at Cambridge’s Cavendish Laboratory he directly observed dislocations in stainless steel and aluminium, explaining metal ductility and enabling strengthening. He co-authored the 1965 “Yellow Bible,” Electron Microscopy of Thin Crystals. Berlin-born Jewish refugee via Kindertransport (1939), he studied natural sciences at Cambridge (PhD 1951), then led Oxford metallurgy as Isaac Wolfson chair (1966–92). FRS 1963, knighted 1975; chaired UKAEA 1982–84. Mentor; Oxford runs a bursary and lecture series in his name. Married Mabel “Steve” Kellar; survived by stepchildren. Died 12 Sept 2025, aged 100.

articles.title: ‘Ball junkie’: some dogs show signs of addiction, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers say terrier and shepherd breeds display greater tendency for addictive-type behaviour
articles.summary: Study in Scientific Reports assessed 105 pet dogs (56 male, 49 female; ages 1–10) for toy-driven “addictive-like” behavior in lab tasks (toy play, isolation with toy, toy made inaccessible, toy vs food puzzle, toy on shelf). Researchers scored craving-like signs (jumping, barking/whining, persistence, skipping food). Thirty-three scored above the data’s half-range; terrier and shepherd breeds overrepresented. High scorers aligned with human criteria (craving, impaired control, salience) and owner questionnaires. Co-author Stefanie Riemer cites a strong genetic component; not all “ball junkies” are addicted. CNRS’s Serge Ahmed notes limited evidence of harm/chronicity. Correction: not “median.” Owners reportedly did little to encourage it; harm defines addiction.

articles.title: Sir John Gurdon obituary
articles.trailText: Biologist who won the Nobel prize for discovering that adult cells can be reprogrammed
articles.summary: Sir John Gurdon (1933-2025), Nobel laureate cell biologist, proved in 1958 that nuclei from differentiated tadpole gut cells can reprogram frog eggs to generate adult animals, establishing nuclear equivalence and cellular reprogramming. He shared the 2012 physiology/medicine Nobel with Shinya Yamanaka, underpinning induced pluripotent stem cells and animal cloning (Dolly). He co-founded Cambridge's Wellcome CRC Institute in 1982, renamed the Gurdon Institute in 2004; worked at Oxford and MRC LMB. Knighted 1995; master of Magdalene College. Famous for an Eton "unsuitable for science" report, he bench-worked into his 90s. Died aged 92 on 7 Oct 2025.

articles.title: Angela Hobart obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives : Anthropological expert on Balinese shadow puppetry who lectured on cross-cultural therapy
articles.summary: Angela Hobart, 86, social anthropologist renowned for Balinese shadow puppetry, authored Dancing Shadows of Bali (1987) and Healing Performances of Bali (2005). Born in Freiburg to Edmund Stinnes and Margiana von Schulze Gaevernitz, she fled to the US in 1941 via Quaker aid, later schooling in Ascona. After art studies in Florence she married anthropologist Mark Hobart (1965; divorced 1982), worked at St George’s, and began Bali fieldwork in 1970. Fast-tracked to a SOAS PhD and an LSE master’s, she lectured at the British Museum and Goldsmiths, founded Centro Incontri Umani (1989) and the Sutasoma Trust (1990), and treated refugees at the Medical Foundation (2012–16). Survived by one child.

articles.title: Nobel prize in chemistry awarded to scientists for work on ‘Hermione’s handbag’
articles.trailText: Trio honoured for developing revolutionary materials for applications ranging from gas storage to drug delivery
articles.summary: Nobel chemistry prize (11m SEK/£871k) to Susumu Kitagawa (Kyoto), Richard Robson (Melbourne) and Omar Yaghi (UC Berkeley) for metal-organic frameworks (MOFs): crystalline networks of metal ions and organic linkers with vast porosity. MOFs enable hydrogen and methane storage, oxygen/nitrogen delivery, CO2 capture, desert-air water harvesting, toxin/PFAS removal, rare-earth recovery and drug delivery. Robson's 1989 copper lattices revealed cavities but were unstable; Kitagawa built robust, tunable, flexible Co/Ni/Zn MOFs; Yaghi's Lego-like syntheses produced netlike and zinc MOFs with football-pitch surface area per grams, yielding Hermione's handbag-scale gas capacity. Prize announced by the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in Stockholm.

articles.title: 3/I Atlas: a rare comet from beyond our solar system is being closely tracked – what can it teach us?
articles.trailText: Only the third interstellar comet ever to be seen contains material from other star systems that can be observed close up
articles.summary: 3I/Atlas, detected in July, is only the third known interstellar comet (after 1I/Oumuamua, 2017; 2I/Borisov, 2019). Estimated 0.44–5.6 km across, it will pass much closer to the Sun than Borisov, likely shedding abundant gas/dust—rare, close-up samples of extrasolar building blocks. Hubble reveals a sunward “anti-tail,” implying uneven sublimation. ESO’s VLT finds a high nickel-to-iron ratio, possibly from sublimating nickel tetracarbonyl and iron pentacarbonyl; unusual polarization could arise from water ice and Mg-rich silicates. Entering near the ecliptic, its path skirts Jupiter, Mars and Venus but poses no threat; closest to Earth ~240 million km (>1.5 AU). While Avi Loeb speculates alien tech, consensus says natural. ESA Mars orbiters imaged its coma; it re-emerges for observing in late November.

articles.title: Jane Goodall’s grasp of chimpanzees and ‘alpha males’ | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: A primatologist’s legacy | Beckett’s influence on Macron | Left over what? | Gilbert & George | A call to Noah Vale
articles.summary: Readers salute Jane Goodall’s legacy beyond primatology—her candour on Trump and Musk and support for resisting political aggression—and urge keeping her name alive, writes Meirion Bowen (London). Another letter riffs on Emmanuel Macron’s fifth prime ministership with Beckett’s “Fail better” and a Godot gag, jibes Peter Declan O’Halloran (Belturbet, Ireland). Domestic notes query “leftover panettone,” countering past “leftover wine” recipes, notes Pete Lavender (Woodthorpe, Nottinghamshire). A reader lauds Jonathan Jones’s Gilbert & George review and plans a Hayward Gallery visit, says Linda Karlsen (Whitstable, Kent). A mondegreen delights—“to Noah Vale”—reports Sue Dean (Whitley Bay, Tyne and Wear). The Guardian invites more letters.

articles.title: Women carry a higher genetic risk of depression, new study says
articles.trailText: Researchers in Australia find 16 genetic variants linked to depression in women but only eight in men
articles.summary: Australia’s QIMR Berghofer-led study in Nature Communications, the largest sex-stratified depression genetics analysis, identified 16 risk variants in women versus 8 in men. Pooled DNA from five cohorts (Australia, Netherlands, US, two UK) included 130,471 women and 64,805 men with major depression, plus 159,521 female and 132,185 male controls. Many loci were shared, but women showed a higher genetic burden and stronger genetic correlations between depression and metabolic traits (BMI, metabolic syndrome). Authors checked sample-size effects; results persisted. Limitation: European ancestry only. Experts say findings support biological drivers and future sex-tailored treatments.

articles.title: Scientist learns he has won Nobel prize while on digital detox in US mountains
articles.trailText: Fred Ramsdell’s wife switched on her phone and screamed – it was full of messages congratulating her husband
articles.summary: Immunologist Fred Ramsdell, 64, discovered he’d won the 2025 Nobel in physiology or medicine during a digital‑detox hike across Idaho, Wyoming and Montana. His wife, Laura O’Neill, powered her phone while fixing their car, triggering a yell he first mistook for a grizzly. The committee, which initially reached only co‑laureate Shimon Sakaguchi (Osaka Univ), later contacted Ramsdell and Mary Brunkow (Institute for Systems Biology, Seattle). The trio share SEK 11m (~£871k) for foundational discoveries on T‑cell function. Ramsdell’s San Francisco lab, Sonoma Biotherapeutics, said he was “off the grid.”

articles.title: Nobel prize in physics awarded to three scientists for work on quantum mechanics
articles.trailText: Trio led experiments that paved the way for the next generation of quantum technologies
articles.summary: Nobel prize in physics 2025 goes to John Clarke (UC Berkeley, UK), Michel Devoret (Yale, France) and John Martinis (UC Santa Barbara, US) for experiments showing macroscopic quantum tunnelling and energy quantisation in superconducting circuits. In 1980s work on Josephson junctions in Clarke’s lab, the team observed voltage blips from whole-circuit tunnelling that followed probabilistic decay, proving quantum effects at circuit scale. The Royal Swedish Academy awarded SEK 11m (~£871k). Their results underpinned superconducting qubits, spurring quantum cryptography and computing; Martinis later led Google’s effort (2014–20). Clarke called the award a surprise; officials hailed quantum theory’s enduring utility.

articles.title: Jane Goodall said she would launch Trump and Musk on one-way trip into space
articles.trailText: Primatologist said in interview released after her death she would also put Putin, Xi and Netanyahu on that spaceship
articles.summary: Netflix’s posthumous documentary Famous Last Words, recorded in March and released days after Jane Goodall died at 91, captures the primatologist saying she’d send certain “alpha” human males on a one-way SpaceX trip: Elon Musk (“the host”), Donald Trump and some of his supporters, plus Vladimir Putin, China’s Xi Jinping, and Israel’s Benjamin Netanyahu and his far-right government. Goodall links the remark to her research on dominance: aggressive alphas fade; strategic, alliance-building ones endure. She describes how group fear and anger are “contagious” in chimpanzees and can be in humans, echoing a 2022 comparison of Trump to a display-driven male chimp. Despite “grim” politics and the climate crisis, she urges hope, civic compassion (Roots & Shoots), and cumulative everyday action.

articles.title: Human stupidity is nothing new in politics | Letters
articles.trailText: Letters: Gregorio Kohon looks at why we accept superficial slogans, pseudoscientific claims and comforting myths from our leaders, and Vaughan Dean writes about ‘Trumpery’
articles.summary: Gregorio Kohon, citing his paper How Could I Have Been So Stupid? and responding to William Davies (A critique of pure stupidity: understanding Trump 2.0, 2 Oct), argues political life is perennially shaped by “structural” stupidity: delusion, myth-making, distorted memory and conspiracy-building. He invokes “bullshit receptivity,” Rick Shenkman’s “wooden-” vs “bone-headedness,” and Bonhoeffer’s 1943 warning that power turns people into vessels for slogans—fueling propaganda, pseudoscience, gaslighting and self-deception. Vaughan Dean adds that “trumpery”—attested since the 15th century as “worthless nonsense,” including an 1851 royal sneer about the Great Exhibition—deserves renewed currency in the Trump era.

articles.title: Nobel prize in medicine awarded to scientists for immune system research
articles.trailText: Mary E Brunkow, Fred Ramsdell and Shimon Sakaguchi win for work on preventing immune system harming body
articles.summary: The 2025 Nobel prize in physiology or medicine went to Mary E Brunkow (Institute for Systems Biology, Seattle), Fred Ramsdell (Sonoma Biotherapeutics, San Francisco) and Shimon Sakaguchi (Osaka University) for discoveries on peripheral immune tolerance. They identified regulatory T cells (Tregs)—mature CD25+ T cells that suppress self-reactive T cells—and the central role of the FoxP3 gene, linking mutations to scurfy mice and human IPEX syndrome. The work reframed self-tolerance beyond thymic deletion, explaining autoimmunity risk and enabling therapies: boosting Tregs for autoimmune disease and transplants; inhibiting Tregs to enhance anti-cancer immunity. Prize: 11m SEK (~£871k). Experts called Tregs the immune system’s brakes, noting vast clinical potential.

articles.title: Starwatch: Draconids meteor shower promises an early-evening treat
articles.trailText: Comet responsible for phenomenon passed close to the sun earlier this year, creating high chance of a meteor storm
articles.summary: October kicks off meteor-shower season, culminating with the Geminids in December, and the Draconids peak on 8 October, favouring early evening viewing. From London, the radiant sits high in the north-west around 20:00 BST, making the shower unusually convenient. Expect slow, graceful meteors, typically ~10 per hour under dark skies; a waning Moon this year will wash out faint ones. However, an outburst is possible: the Draconids originate from comet 21P/Giacobini-Zinner (6.6-year period). With its latest close approach in March, odds improve for above-average rates—sometimes hundreds per hour—though not guaranteed.

articles.title: Adrian Mayer obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Anthropologist at Soas University of London who carried out an influential study of the Indian caste system in the 1950s
articles.summary: Adrian Mayer, who has died aged 102, was a Soas social anthropologist whose 1954-55 fieldwork in Jamgod, Madhya Pradesh, under ANU auspices produced Caste and Kinship in Central India (1960), revealing caste as a kinship- and belief-based order distinct from wealth/class. He later examined caste among overseas Indian communities. Educated at Bryanston and St John’s College (Annapolis), he served in India with the Friends Ambulance Unit (1944-46), meeting Gandhi and Nehru; studied Hindi at Soas, then earned LSE diploma and PhD. At Soas from 1956, he retired professor in 1985; editor of Man (1964-69), RAI president (1983-85), SSRC chair (1973-79). Publications continued to 2012. He was widower of artist Kaia; survivors: daughters Claudia, Camilla; grandchildren Zoe, Georgina.

articles.title: Was prehistory a feminist paradise?
articles.trailText: Visions of matriarchal utopia may be wishful thinking, but there’s growing evidence of women wielding power
articles.summary: Ancient DNA and isotope analysis overturn simple myths of a prehistoric matriarchal “golden age,” revealing wide variation in gender systems rather than a single switch to patriarchy. Engels’ agriculture-to-patrilineality model and Gimbutas’s Old Europe hypothesis are partly supported and partly contradicted: matrilineal, often matrilocal, groups existed globally. But matrilineality didn’t mean female rule; men’s brothers often decided. Examples include a 10th‑century elite in Chaco Canyon and an earlier farming community in eastern China. Power was multifaceted—soft and hard—evidenced by joint Bronze Age rulers, female warriors/hunters/shamans, and Iron Age Celtic pockets of matrilineality. Economy and conflict shaped norms (e.g., Tibet’s market shift; internal strife favors patrilocality). Modern survivals: Mosuo, Hopi.

articles.title: Signs of life? Why Saturn moon offers hope of finding ET in Earth’s back yard
articles.trailText: Discovery of wide array of carbon-based substances on Enceladus shows solar system is fertile hunting ground
articles.summary: Discovery that Enceladus is venting a wider array of carbon-based compounds has raised the odds it is habitable, scientists say. Saturn’s sixth-largest moon (1.27bn km away) already boasts complex organics, a global liquid-water ocean and likely hydrothermal vents, with pH, salinity and temperature within life-friendly bounds, notes CNRS’s Caroline Freissinet. Researchers argue nearby targets beat exoplanets for biosignature hunts: distant worlds require planet-scale atmospheric changes, transits, and can’t reveal past life, says SETI’s Nathalie Cabrol. NASA and ESA are developing in‑situ Enceladus missions; Freissinet is building molecular detectors. Europa remains a top alternative. ESA’s Jörn Helbert says findings will recalibrate habitability: detection would energize exoplanet searches; a null result may force redefining life’s likelihood. Finding life locally would imply galactic ubiquity.

articles.title: ‘Surprisingly creamy’: as a fermentista, how could I resist making ant yoghurt?
articles.trailText: Findings of study into fermentation process behind dairy product could serve as toolkit for creating new foods
articles.summary: University of Copenhagen scientists investigated a revived Turkish/Bulgarian “ant yoghurt,” after interest from Copenhagen’s two‑Michelin‑star Alchemist. Village recollections: warm fresh milk, add four red wood ants, cover, and bury in an ant mound overnight. Lab work (iScience) confirmed a co‑fermentation: ants’ formic acid lowers pH, enabling their acid‑loving microbes; ant/bacterial enzymes break milk proteins. Only live ants had the right microbiome. Flavors varied (herbaceous/lemony; thicker). Risks: some ants carry liver‑fluke parasites; red wood ants are declining, so scaling is unethical. Applications: ant‑derived cultures could seed plant‑based yoghurts or novel sourdough flavors. Rutgers’ Martin Blaser says this could diversify tastes beyond dominant industrial strains. A home batch was “surprisingly creamy.”

articles.title: Fungi finds: UK citizen scientists make rare pink and purple discoveries
articles.trailText: Plantlife charity enlisted help of 850 volunteers to look for waxcaps in places such as private gardens
articles.summary: Plantlife mobilised 850 UK volunteers to survey waxcap fungi across gardens, graveyards, sheep pastures and lawns, uncovering 300 new sites for pink waxcap (Porpolomopsis calyptriformis, IUCN Vulnerable) and 18 for violet coral (Clavaria zollingeri). This significantly extends British Mycological Society records (previously ~1,000 pink waxcap, 183 violet coral sites). These internationally rare species thrive in nutrient-poor ancient grasslands, now pressured by development, intensive farming and ill-sited tree-planting; fertilisers, pesticides, ploughing and soil disturbance harm them. Waxcaps’ bright colours aid novice ID. Waxcap Watch 2025 runs 15 Sep–31 Dec. They are key indicators of remnant grassland and the UK bears stewardship responsibility.

articles.title: China remembers ‘guiding light’ Jane Goodall’s wildlife conservation work
articles.trailText: Tributes paid to late British primatologist whose institute trained thousands of Chinese on protecting animals
articles.summary: China mourned Jane Goodall, 91, as a 'guiding light,' highlighting her institute’s deep footprint: Roots & Shoots worked with 1,000+ schools in 25 provinces, training 10,000 teachers and educating countless students. State media cited her long relationship with China—her 17th visit last year and a CCTV interview noting ecological improvements. Scientists Sun Xin and Shi Jun praised her impact. She urged China to lead in ending fossil fuels after Yangtze basin degradation and rare protests spurred greener policy. Online tributes surged—Weibo hashtag 120m views, hundreds of millions of interactions; Bilibili users echoed thanks. Filmmaker Xi Zhilong hailed her enduring influence.

articles.title: Dame Jane Goodall obituary
articles.trailText: Pioneering scientist whose breakthrough studies of chimpanzees changed how the animals were perceived and led to greater protection
articles.summary: Dame Jane Goodall (1934–2025), pioneering primatologist, transformed understanding of chimpanzees after 1960 Gombe discoveries of meat-eating and termite “fishing” tool use, recasting apes as deliberative beings. Backed by Louis Leakey, she built the Gombe Stream Research Centre, the longest-running great-ape field station, and earned a Cambridge PhD (1966) without an undergraduate degree. National Geographic-featured author of In the Shadow of Man (1971) and The Chimpanzees of Gombe (1986), she overcame skeptics (eg Solly Zuckerman). From mid-1980s she focused on conservation, founding the Jane Goodall Institute (1977), later UN Messenger of Peace (2002) and dame (2003). Marriages: Hugo van Lawick (one son); Derek Bryceson. Died 1 Oct 2025, 91.

articles.title: ‘A remarkable ability to inspire’: global tributes pour in for Jane Goodall
articles.trailText: Barack Obama, Prince William and Tanzanian president among many to mark death of primatologist at age of 91
articles.summary: Jane Goodall, pioneering primatologist and conservationist, died at 91 in her sleep in Los Angeles while on a speaking tour. Tributes poured in from Barack Obama, Prince William, Tanzania’s president Samia Suluhu Hassan, Chris Packham, Prof Ben Garrod, and others including Leonardo DiCaprio and Tim Cook. Her Gombe research revealed chimpanzee tool use, hunting and rich social lives, overturning orthodoxy and inspiring generations—especially women in science. Admirers hailed her tireless climate and biodiversity advocacy, globe-trotting outreach (often 300 days/year), and enduring legacy centering Africa and primate conservation. Leaders from Re:wild, IPBES, Mighty Earth and the African Wildlife Foundation vowed to carry her work forward.

articles.title: Jane Goodall, world-renowned primatologist, dies aged 91
articles.trailText: Jane Goodall Institute says ‘tireless advocate’ for natural world died in California during US speaking tour
articles.summary: Jane Goodall, 91, died of natural causes in California while on a US speaking tour, her institute said. The primatologist began studying chimpanzees at Gombe, Tanzania, in 1960, documenting tool use and meat-eating and reshaping ethology. She founded the Jane Goodall Institute in 1977 and Roots & Shoots in 1991 (youth network in ~100 countries), and campaigned against animal testing and inadequate zoos. Honors include UN Messenger of Peace (2002), damehood (2004) and the US Medal of Freedom (2025). Recently on stage in New York, she drew global tributes from the UN and Greenpeace. A pandemic-era podcaster, she urged urgent climate and biodiversity action.

articles.title: Prospect of life on Saturn’s moons rises after discovery of organic substances
articles.trailText: Scientists studying water vapour plume from Enceladus find presence of complex molecules that could harbour life
articles.summary: Cassini data of Enceladus's south-pole plume reveal previously undetected complex organics in fresh ice grains, boosting habitability prospects. Using the Cosmic Dust Analyzer, Nozair Khawaja's team (Freie Univ Berlin) analyzed minutes-old plume grains - purer than older E-ring material - and reported in Nature Astronomy that multiple carbon-based molecules originate from the subsurface saltwater ocean. The James Webb Space Telescope imaged the plume extending about 6,000 miles. Findings do not prove life but indicate active chemistry supplying prebiotic compounds, plus liquid water and energy. ESA targets ~2042 for an orbiter with plume flythroughs and a south-polar lander to seek biosignatures.

articles.title: Human skin cells are turned into eggs in fertility breakthrough
articles.trailText: Scientists say their early-stage work could help older women or same-sex male couples have children
articles.summary: Researchers at Oregon Health & Science University, led by Shoukhrat Mitalipov, generated human eggs from skin cells using somatic cell nuclear transfer, building on Dolly-era cloning. Enucleated donor oocytes received skin-cell nuclei (46 chromosomes); after sperm fertilization, roscovitine induced extrusion of roughly half the chromosomes into a polar body. Resulting chromosome pairing was random, producing aneuploid embryos; fewer than 10% of 82 eggs reached the day 5/6 IVF transfer stage, and none were cultured beyond six days. Published in Nature Communications, the proof-of-concept could aid older women, cancer survivors, and same-sex male couples, but safety, efficiency, and governance may take about a decade to address.

articles.title: Study links greater inequality to structural changes in children’s brains
articles.trailText: Researchers say findings show inequality creates toxic environment and reducing it is ‘a public health imperative’
articles.summary: Analysis of >10,000 US youths (ABCD cohort; ages ~10–11) published in Nature Mental Health finds that state-level income inequality—not individual family income—is linked to altered neurodevelopment: reduced cortical surface area and changed functional connectivity in regions for emotion, attention, memory and language. Inequality hotspots (NY, CT, CA, FL) vs more equal (UT, WI, MN, VT). MRI showed cortical surface/thickness changes and network alterations across income strata. Brain changes predicted poorer mental health (depression/anxiety) at 6 and 18 months. Work by King’s College London, Harvard, York; authors Rakesh, Patel, Pickett call reducing inequality a public health imperative. Funders: BBRF, UKRI MRC, NIMH.

articles.title: Patrick Vaughan obituary
articles.trailText: Epidemiologist who advised health services in Tanzania, Bangladesh and the UK’s Department for International Development
articles.summary: Patrick Vaughan (1937–2025), leading epidemiologist and LSHTM Tropical Epidemiology Unit director, advised WHO, World Bank, NHS, DFID, the UK Cabinet—and Live Aid (1985) on Ethiopia relief. He shifted LSHTM toward multidisciplinary, field-led public health, founding the Centre for Evaluation (1979) and the journal Health Policy and Planning (1986). Work spanned PNG, Tanzania (public health), Bangladesh (1988 homemade ORS trial; later cholera/Aids), and Brazil (breastfeeding/first 1,000 days policy). He stressed vaccine logistics and community buy-in; foresaw diabetes, ageing, urbanisation. Author of 120+ papers; co-wrote Practical Epidemiology (2021); CBE 1998. Overcame chaotic childhood; reputed Piggy inspiration; died 87.

articles.title: Did you solve it? Ungoogleable and unhinged – ten hilarious visual teasers
articles.trailText: The solutions to today’s puzzles
articles.summary: Solutions to ten say-what-you-see visual rebus teasers: 1) Jaw-Jaw Well → George Orwell; 2) Olive Ear Coal Man → Olivia Colman; 3) Pot Eight Toes → Potatoes; 4) Raising a toast; 5) Pie Rats of the Caribbean → Pirates of the Caribbean; 6) Ewe Tuba → YouTuber; 7) Shakes Beer → Shakespeare; 8) Scarf Ace → Scarface; 9) Rat Tattoo E → Ratatouille; 10) Newt On Eye Sack → Isaac Newton. From Say What Ewe See: A Very Silly Visual Puzzle Book by Louis Catlett (UK release Oct 9). The column runs alternate Mondays since 2015; reader puzzle submissions invited.

articles.title: Can you solve it? Ungoogleable and unhinged – ten hilarious visual teasers
articles.trailText: Riotous rebus riddles
articles.summary: Guardian’s Can You Solve It? features ten “say what you see” visual rebus teasers—deliberately ungoogleable, gleefully silly, aimed at eliciting chuckles or groans. Readers are asked to avoid spoilers and to suggest new out-loud phrases with double meanings. Solutions promised at 5pm UK, later updated with answers. All puzzles come from Say What Ewe See: A Very Silly Visual Puzzle Book (UK release Oct 9), touted as a stocking filler. Also noted: Briton Freddie Hand won the World Puzzle Championship, the first UK winner since 1992. Column runs alternate Mondays since 2015; submissions invited via email.

articles.title: Starwatch: Sunlight and dust combine to create the soft glow of zodiacal light
articles.trailText: Choose the darkest site you can find an hour before dawn twilight to observe one of the more subtle celestial effects
articles.summary: This week offers prime views of zodiacal light: a faint triangular glow from sunlight scattering off interplanetary dust shed by comets and asteroid collisions. Around the recent equinox, the ecliptic tilts steeply, enhancing the effect. For the UK/northern hemisphere, pick a very dark site with a clear eastern horizon and start about an hour before dawn (~4am UK). Look toward Cancer and Leo; the glow mimics false dawn but appears as a wedge. In the southern hemisphere, the view reverses: about an hour after sunset, a soft wedge rises from the western horizon through Virgo and Libra.

articles.title: Being organised and active may be predictor of longer life, study finds
articles.trailText: Researchers find specific self-descriptions predict mortality risks better than broader categories such as extraversion
articles.summary: Specific personality self-descriptions beat broad Big Five traits at predicting mortality, a Journal of Psychosomatic Research study of >22,000 adults across four cohorts (6–28 years’ follow-up) finds. Calling oneself “active” predicted a 21% lower death risk after adjusting for age, sex and medical conditions; lively, organised, responsible, hard‑working, thorough and helpful also tracked longer life. Neuroticism facets (moody, anxious, easily upset) predicted earlier death. Nuances cumulatively outperformed openness/conscientiousness/extraversion/agreeableness/neuroticism. Lifestyle/clinical factors (smoking, BMI, activity, chronic illness) explained part, not all. Authors René Mõttus (Edinburgh) and Páraic O’Súilleabháin (Limerick) stress non-determinism; experts urge integrating personality screening in healthcare.

articles.title: Friday briefing: The Huntington’s treatment is a ray of light for victims of a brutal disease
articles.trailText: In today’s newsletter: A gene therapy trial has successfully treated Huntington’s for the first time – one of several recent groundbreaking medical advances bringing hope in gloomy times
articles.summary: A first-in-human success for Huntington’s: gene therapy slowed disease progression by 75% over three years after a single neurosurgical infusion. UCL scientists used a harmless virus to deliver gene‑silencing material directly into two brain regions over 12–20 hours, bypassing the blood–brain barrier and stopping production of toxic mutant huntingtin. Around 6,000–10,000 Britons have Huntington’s; 20,000 are carriers (50% inheritance risk). The advance sits alongside new Alzheimer’s drugs and rapid diagnostics (£100 blood test, three‑minute scan) and a blood thinner beating aspirin. Yet FDA layoffs and a >40% NIH cut threaten progress, as the FDA fast‑tracks the therapy.

articles.title: Don’t look up: how Trump’s deregulation drive could obscure the stars and threaten our access to space
articles.trailText: Astronomers are warning that the proliferation of satellite constellations like SpaceX’s Starlink, are making their work harder than it’s ever been
articles.summary: Trump’s August executive order to streamline rocket launches—cutting environmental reviews, easing safety rules, and preempting some state limits—could accelerate mega-constellations. FAA licensing has surged; launches could nearly quadruple. Astronomers warn Starlink already owns two‑thirds of satellites: ~8,000 in LEO, approval for 4,000 more, filings up to 42,000; rivals from Amazon and China could push totals toward 100,000. Researchers report telescope images streaked, plus atmospheric impacts from burned-up hardware (ozone, opacity). Debris risk is rising: 43,000 tracked objects and ~1.2m 1–10cm pieces, raising Kessler fears. Starlink’s avoidance helps, but coordination gaps remain. Critics urge stricter regulation, fearing action only after a catastrophic collision.

articles.title: Study of 1m-year-old skull points to earlier origins of modern humans
articles.trailText: Skull found in China may be Homo longi, potentially revising understanding of human evolution
articles.summary: A 1m-year-old Hubei, China skull (Yunxian 2) digitally rebuilt via CT, surface scanning and virtual modeling appears closer to Homo longi ("dragon man") than Homo erectus, despite its low, squat braincase and jutting jaw. Researchers argue it is the closest fossil to the sapiens-Neanderthal-Denisovan split, pushing divergence back >=400k years, roughly doubling sapiens' time depth and hinting at western Asian, not strictly African, origins. A phylogenetic analysis recovers five major lineages over 800k years: Asian erectus, heidelbergensis, sapiens, Neanderthals, and Homo longi/Denisovans. Published in Science; results contest genetic models, with experts urging ancient DNA tests.

articles.title: Supercentenarian gives scientists insight on secrets of healthy old age
articles.trailText: Tests on Maria Branyas Morera, who was world’s oldest person before she died aged 117, gave doctors a trove of discoveries
articles.summary: Spanish researchers led by Dr Manel Esteller (Josep Carreras Leukaemia Research Institute, Barcelona) conducted multi-omic analyses on supercentenarian Maria Branyas Morera a year before her death at 117. She recovered from COVID-19 at 113. The work separates being old from being sick. Despite extreme senescent markers, including exceptionally short telomeres, immune ageing and leukemia-associated mutations, she showed protective traits: cardiocerebral risk-lowering gene variants, efficient lipid/cholesterol metabolism, unexpectedly low systemic inflammation, and a youthful gut microbiome rich in Bifidobacterium. Epigenetic clocks read 10-15 years younger than chronological age. Lifestyle likely helped: normal weight, yogurt-rich diet, no smoking/drinking, strong social ties. Findings may reveal druggable targets to extend healthspan.

articles.title: Huntington’s disease treated successfully for first time in UK gene therapy trial
articles.trailText: Surgical procedure to treat devastating illness slowed progress of disease by 75% in patients after three years
articles.summary: Huntington’s disease has been treated successfully for the first time in a UK-led gene therapy trial, slowing progression by 75% at three years. Led by Prof Sarah Tabrizi (UCL), a single-shot, 12–20-hour neurosurgical infusion uses a modified virus to deliver DNA that switches off mutant huntingtin. In 29 patients (UK/US), high-dose recipients had ~75% slowing across motor, cognitive and daily-living measures, plus lower neurofilament levels. Developer uniQure plans a US filing early next year. Complex and costly, the therapy could enable presymptomatic use. UK prevalence: 6k–10k patients and ~20k carriers; full data pending.

articles.title: Geology could crush hopes of extracting all North Sea’s oil and gas
articles.trailText: The remaining fields tend to be smaller, more remote and more technically challenging to drill into
articles.summary: UK debate over North Sea drilling collides with geology. Despite political calls—Trump urging Starmer to “drill, baby, drill”, Tory leader Kemi Badenoch to “maximise extraction”, and Reform UK making drilling a day‑one priority—production peaked in 1999 and is now less than half. Remaining prospects are smaller, farther offshore and technically harder. Newcastle’s Mark Ireland says even looser licensing can’t overcome subsurface limits. New licences might lift output marginally, aiding a strategic, time‑limited bridge away from gas imports (as Nils Pratley argues), but projects must compete for capital with easier Middle East/North Africa barrels. Thin reserves and wary investors risk making expansion a political mirage.

articles.title: Letter: Margaret Boden obituary
articles.trailText: Andy Holyer writes: She did not suffer fools gladly and had a mind like a steel trap
articles.summary: Andy Holyer writes a tribute letter recalling Margaret “Maggie” Boden at the University of Sussex in 1991: hearing her on BBC Radio 4’s Today show, where, amid fashionable “end of history” debates, she rebutted an interviewee’s “end of science” claim in under 30 seconds. Holyer depicts Boden as a warm, loyal friend who nevertheless “did not suffer fools gladly,” praising her razor-sharp intellect—“a mind like a steel trap”—and concluding he never knew a finer one. The anecdote highlights her public intellectual clarity, speed of thought, and uncompromising rigor. Written in response to her obituary, the note memorializes her Sussex years and incisive presence on UK airwaves.

articles.title: Fresh approaches needed to tackle political ‘age of rage’, US study suggests
articles.trailText: Researchers show interventions to reduce hostility only have short-term impact and there is no ‘magical fix’
articles.summary: US researchers analyzed 25 studies (mostly US), testing 77 interventions to reduce partisan animosity. Average effect: +5.4 points in warmth toward the opposing party on a 101-point scale—modest and smaller than routine public fluctuations, unlikely to alter misinformation beliefs or support for democratic norms. Effects faded fast: about 75% gone after one week, nearly all by two. Combining interventions (n=2,284) or repeating them three times (n=5,078) offered no advantage over a single exposure. Published in PNAS, the study argues no “magical fix”; durable change likely requires incentive reforms constraining elite/social-media polarization. Kurt Gray notes lasting cross-aisle relationships can still help.

articles.title: Chris Calladine obituary
articles.trailText: Other lives: Structural engineer whose cross-disciplinary work in molecular biology contributed to our understanding of DNA
articles.summary: Chris Calladine, aged 90, was a Cambridge professor of structural mechanics and fellow of the Royal Society and Royal Academy of Engineering who bridged engineering and molecular biology. Working with Aaron Klug from the 1970s, he applied geodesic‑dome mechanics to microbiological structures, advancing models of bacterial flagella (1975), DNA (1982) and protein nanotubes (2001). His 1982 Calladine’s rules explained DNA bending and switching between forms after 1981 crystallography revised the Watson‑Crick view. He wrote the standard text Understanding DNA (1992). Beyond biophysics, he solved deep‑sea pipeline buckling and NASA helium‑balloon wrinkling. Nottingham-born; MIT MSc; taught at Cambridge 1960–retirement; married Mary Webb; three children, three grandchildren.

articles.title: Starwatch: find a clear southern horizon to view moon’s Antares conjunction
articles.trailText: Conjunction is easier to spot from southern hemisphere because Antares is in southern constellation of Scorpius
articles.summary: The waxing crescent moon makes a close conjunction with Antares this week (around 22 Sep 2025). From London, look south-west about 19:30 BST with a clear southern horizon—ideally from a hill—as the pair are already setting in twilight. The moon is ~5.5 days old with just under 30% illumination. Visibility is far better in the southern hemisphere, where Antares (Scorpius) sits higher and the pair draw even closer. From parts of the southern Indian Ocean and Bouvet Island, the moon will occult Antares completely.

articles.title: Tylenol guidelines: is it safe to use paracetamol during pregnancy?
articles.trailText: The Trump administration is reportedly set to connect Tylenol, also known as paracetamol or acetaminophen, with autism, going against medical recommendations
articles.summary: Washington Post reports the Trump administration will claim prenatal Tylenol (acetaminophen/paracetamol) raises autism risk, despite guidelines. Trump teased he had found an answer to autism; health secretary RFK Jr cites environmental toxins. ACOG, RCOG and the NHS recommend paracetamol as first-line for pain/fever in pregnancy; NSAIDs in late pregnancy carry risks. Untreated fever/pain raises risks of congenital defects, preterm birth, low birth weight, miscarriage, and maternal complications. Evidence remains inconclusive: a 2024 Swedish cohort (2.5m) found no causal link; a 2025 review saw associations but not causation; large 2025 European/Japanese studies suggest confounding. US retailer lawsuits were dismissed in 2024; appeal pending.

articles.title: Longer words and real reflection: the science behind a convincing apology
articles.trailText: People expect effort, not a token ‘I’m sorry’, but be careful not to over-script your acknowledgment of mistakes
articles.summary: New research finds apologies using longer words seem more sincere because listeners infer extra effort, though over-scripting backfires. Psychologist Tara Quinn-Cirillo says genuine remorse needs vulnerability and three cues: insight, reflection, behavior change. Case studies: Ashton Kutcher/Mila Kunis’s stiff video after backing Danny Masterson worsened perceptions; Liam Byrne’s florid mea culpa over his "no money left" note split opinion; Boris Johnson’s Covid apologies sounded hollow, later retracted; Harvey Weinstein’s statement deflected blame while threatening suits. Institutions, too: Florence’s 2008 gesture to Dante and the Catholic church’s 1996 grudging Galileo admission lacked contrition.

articles.title: Huge crater under North Sea was created by asteroid impact, scientists say
articles.trailText: Silverpit crater off Yorkshire coast was caused by cathedral-sized asteroid that set off 100-metre tsunami 43m years ago
articles.summary: Scientists say the Silverpit structure, 80 miles off Yorkshire and 700 metres beneath the North Sea, is an impact crater formed about 43 million years ago by a York Minster-sized (about 160 m) asteroid, generating 100 m tsunami waves. New high-resolution seismic imaging, microscopic cuttings, and numerical models reveal a 2-mile-wide crater with a central peak and a 12-mile ring of concentric faults, overturning salt-tectonics claims. Discovered in 2002, a 2009 Geological Society vote was 80–20 against impact. Led by Uisdean Nicholson (Heriot-Watt) with NERC funding, the study appears in Nature Communications. Silverpit is the UK’s only known impact crater; marine examples are rare (33).

articles.title: Country diary: It’s phallic, it smells of death – and it’s good enough to eat | Michael White
articles.trailText: Cranbrook, Kent: The wood here suddenly smells of autumn, and the smelliest fungus of all – the common stinkhorn – is also delicious
articles.summary: Cranbrook, Kent diary evokes autumn’s damp, fungal scent and a search-by-smell for the common stinkhorn (Phallus impudicus). Found among bracken, its unmistakably phallic fruiting body is coated in fetid gleba—carrion-scented slime that attracts flies, which then ferry spores on their feet. Edible but unloved, it’s often eaten immature inside a jelly “witch’s egg,” with a radish-like bite. The author instead dries and grinds mature stinkhorns to deliver aged-beef-like umami to vegan dishes, flavor born of controlled decomposition. This solitary specimen is left to spread spores. The piece trails the Country Diary anthology Under the Changing Skies (2018–2024).

articles.title: Teflon diet, garlic milk and zebra cows triumph at 2025 Ig Nobel prizes
articles.trailText: Researchers into idea to blend powdered PTFE into food as a zero-calorie filler to curb hunger win chemistry prize
articles.summary: At the 2025 Ig Nobel Prizes (Boston University), laureates honored quirky science: Chemistry to Dr Rotem Naftalovich (Rutgers) for proposing powdered PTFE (Teflon) as zero‑calorie food filler—tested in chocolate bars, rebuffed by FDA. Peace to German/Dutch/UK team showing a vodka shot subtly improves foreign‑language performance. Aviation: ethanol-dosed Egyptian fruit bats slowed and mis‑echolocated. Paediatrics: maternal garlic made babies suckle longer. Physics: cacio e pepe phase transition causing clumping. Nutrition: Togolese rainbow lizards preferred “four cheeses” pizza. Engineering: UV shoe‑rack deodorizer that singed trainers. Psychology: bogus “high IQ” boosts narcissism. Biology: zebra‑striped cows got fewer fly bites. Literature: William Bean’s 35‑year nail growth logs.

articles.title: A hi-tech health prediction that I could do without | Brief letters
articles.trailText: Brief letters: Worried sick | Waking the dead | Saint George’s flag | Donald Trump’s state visit to Britain
articles.summary: Guardian brief letters: An AI tool predicting risk for 1,000 diseases worries Sam White (Lewes, East Sussex), who dreads a 30% five-year prognosis. Patrick Cosgrove (Bucknell, Shropshire) calls reviving the dodo (gone 300 years) futile, preferring cooperative Homo neanderthalensis. On St George's flag co-opted by the far right, Liz Conmy (Oxford) proposes a 'reclaim' heart emblem. Carol Haines (Yealmpton, Devon) recalls Bury's 'Weave now' sign. On Donald Trump, Geoffrey Cobb (Deal, Kent) notes emigrants fled such rule; Alan Barnes (Congleton, Cheshire) jokes about a 51st state visit (reports: 14 & 17 Sept).
